prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Legal Bases Used by the Courts for the Protection of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: It has been suggested that an action for breach of confidential information may be best treated as an action sui generis.[1] The Supreme Court of Canada has explicitly accepted the view that an action for breach of confidence may be characterized as a sui generis hybrid which springs from multiple roots in equity and the common law: see both Sopinka J.'s dissent in International Corona Resources Ltd. v. Lac Minerals Ltd.,[2] and Cadbury Schweppes Inc. v. FBI Foods Ltd.[3]
In his article “Restitution of Benefits Obtained in Breach of Another's Confidence”,[4] Gareth Jones states that:

Confidential information is conceptually very much sui generis. It is an intangible; and, consequently, it would be “wrong to confuse the physical records with [the information] itself … for if you put them on a duplicator and produce one hundred copies you have certainly not multiplied your asset in proportion.” It has, too, the quality that it may be transmitted to a limited class without destroying its value; so, know-how “can be communicated to or shared with others outside the manufacturer's own business,” for example under license …[5]
The Supreme Court of Canada and the New Zealand Court of Appeal have also accepted the theory of a synthesized sui generis wrong relating to broken confidences.[6]
One American commentator is of the view that:

The presence of the five idea theories needlessly complicates the law. Traditional contract and trade secret doctrines provide more workable standards and can produce fairer, more uniform results which are more nearly in line with the pervasive policy concerns of providing an incentive to invent while protecting free use of ideas in competition.[7]

The House of Lords has stated that the concept of fusion of the courts of law and equity requires more than the concurrent administration of traditional jurisprudence; what is required is a rationalization and synthesis of rules into a single code.[8]
United Scientific Holdings Ltd. v. Burnley Borough Council, [1978] A.C. 904 (H.L.), at p. 943; Vokes Ltd. v. Heather (1945), 62 R.P.C. 135 (C.A.), at p. 141.

(3d) 449 at p. 482, 162 D.L.R. (4th) 111; Embrace-Air Inc. v. Western Star Trucks Holding Ltd. (2000), 3 B.L.R. (3d) 254 (B.C.S.C.); Novawest Resources Inc. v. Anglo American Exploration (Canada) Ltd., 2006 BCSC 769.
